Description: Rim and body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery Droop cup; interior glazed black with reserved band near bottom of lip; exterior: lip glazed black, two brown bands in handle zone above black-figure decoration, all to left, consisting of part of fighting warrior (helmet, raised right hand with spear), followed by woman (flesh in added white; added red dot for iris, fillet, long garment, rosettes and central dots on black himation), and three nude youths (upper parts only; red hair; two with red rings round nipples) holding a spear upright in right hand and with mock inscriptions between them; at right, muzzle of horse (mouth open).
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of Louvre F28 (ABV p. 199, no. 3)
Attributed to: The Painter of the Nicosia Olpe (Paralipomena)
Curator's comments: On the Droop cup, see Beazley and Payne 1929, 270-1, no. 59 and Ure, P. N. 'Droop Cups', Journal of Hellenic Studies 52, 1932, 55-71.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.44)
Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 271, no. 60)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 425, no. B673)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0600) (Phase 1)
Beazley 1971 / Paralipomena, Additions to Attic Black-Figure Vase-Painters and to Attic Red-Figure Vase-Painters (197, 18)
